Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cowen Mr. Cowen
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach thought it up.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: On that basis the Government is looking at the remaining arguments in regard to the Bill.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cowen Mr. Cowen
Speaker.P: That is the problem with being a conqueror. There is too much to prove.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: We are taking due account of ideas and proposals from all sides on Committee Stage and we will come forward with appropriate amendments on Report Stage in light of that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach agree that if it is proposed to establish a tribunal of inquiry, the immediate urgency about getting a result within days of the Compellability Bill is removed? Will the Government consider deeply the points made by the committee? It is the view of all committee members that these are matters of fundamental importance for Irish democracy that should not be rushed through with regard to the Buchanan report.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Joe Jacob
Speaker.P: This should not be debated.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: I agree that the Compellability Bill is a matter of fundamental importance but it was not dealt with by any Government since 1970. Every Government knew we needed compellability legislation, including Governments in which the Deputy's party was represented.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Speaker.P: Now we know why.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: This Government has introduced compellability legislation and intends to enact it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. McDowell Mr. M. McDowell
Speaker.P: The permanent government does not want it.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: We intend to do so in such a way as to be consistent with the separation of powers. Then we will not have a situation where the Oireachtas attempts to trespass on the province of the courts or the reverse.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: Nor should the Government trespass on the Oireachtas. I refer to Article 28 of the Constitution.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Joe Jacob
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach, without interruption.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: We will ensure that the rights of Members in this House to information, be they in Government or Opposition, are properly protected. The Government is taking all the necessary care to deal with this matter promptly and fully. Regardless of any contingencies or hypotheses referred to by the Deputy, it is important that this matter be thoroughly dealt with in any event and that is what is happening.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dempsey Mr. Dempsey
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach acknowledge that this Compellability Bill was 90 per cent drafted and almost ready for publication when he came into office? It has taken him three years to get it as far as it is and he is reversing a number of the provisions.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Speaker.P: The draft was wrong.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dempsey Mr. Dempsey
Speaker.P: The draft was too wide. It has been narrowed by the Government.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: The Deputy's party was in office, or perhaps he would say almost in office, for seven years prior to the accession to office of this Government. It had not introduced this legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: It is a mess.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: This Government has introduced this legislation, will enact it and will preside in the next Dáil over its operation.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Quill Miss Quill
Speaker.P: Hopefully we will have a tribunal but I acknowledge that the Taoiseach has over the weekend found himself on the road to Damascus.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The road to Nobber.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: The Deputy is on the road to Castlepollard.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cowen Mr. Cowen
Speaker.P: It is the Bruton shuffle.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Joe Jacob
Speaker.P: Deputy Quill is in possession.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Quill Miss Quill
Speaker.P: When will the expert group proposed for the evaluation of the regional technical colleges be put in place? Will there be a student input into the deliberations of that body?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Joe Jacob
Speaker.P: That might be more appropriate as a parliamentary question.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: I like to answer any questions posed by the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: A Deputy A Deputy
Speaker.P: The teacher's pet.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: I note the contrast.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: I give brief answers to Deputy Harney's questions and lengthy answers to Deputy Quill but I answer all of them. This matter is being vigorously pursued by the Minister for Education, who intends to ensure that decisions will be taken at an early date. At this stage the membership of the committee is being finalised and I expect the Minister will make an announcement reasonably soon. The points expressed by the Deputy on composition will be borne in mind.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Quill Miss Quill
Speaker.P: A student input.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: Since Easter is early, on 30 March, and the Social Welfare Bill, little as there is in it, will have to be passed at that time, could the Taoiseach tell me when it is intended to publish the Bill and bring it before the House? It will have to be very early. Fr. Healy got it right. It is good on the rhetoric but not good for the poor.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: The Deputy really means he will have little to say about the Bill because he will not find anything to criticise.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: We will have plenty to say.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: The Deputy made a slip. The Social Welfare Bill will be published before the end of this month. It will provide major changes — better provisions for carers——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Nonsense. What about the poor?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: ——better provisions for the qualifications for old age pensions, large increases in various social welfare benefits, a general improvement for those in receipt of social welfare and a sharing of the benefits of prosperity.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Durkan Mr. Durkan
Speaker.P: All of which the Deputy's party could have done in Government.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. Woods Dr. Woods
Speaker.P: Even as spokesman for equality and law reform I pointed out faults in social welfare legislation. The Bill will give an opportunity to point out many more.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Sargent Mr. Sargent
Speaker.P: On the Chemical Weapons Protection Bill, can the Taoiseach tell me when it is proposed to publish this legislation and for what reason does it come under the Department of Enterprise and Employment? It seems an unlikely Bill for that Department.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. O'Rourke Mrs. O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Deputy Rabbitte is the chemical weapon.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: This matter concerns industrial product and therefore is dealt with by the Department responsible for industry. The legislation will be introduced in the next month or so.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: Now that the prison authorities and the Department of Justice officials dealing with the prisons have said those prisons are in crisis, and there will be no movement on additional places for two years because of the Government's decision to delay for over a year the Castlerea and Mountjoy prisons, has the Taoiseach any plans to try to deal with the matter on a short-term basis?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: The Deputy is characteristically misinformed on this matter. This Government is providing a planned series of additions to the number of prison places, including the opening of Castlerea, a second prison in Wheatfield and a number of other proposals of which the Deputy is well aware.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: How long have we been waiting for this?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: The record of this Government in regard to the provision of additional prison places is in marked contrast——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: There were 4,000 prison releases last year.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: ——to the record of the Deputy's Government from 1987 when no additional prison places were provided.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: That is not what the polls say.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dempsey Mr. Dempsey
Speaker.P: Or the Taoiseach's statement that there were too many in prison.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: Was I so misinformed when I read that when the Minister for Justice was out of the country the Minister for Finance and the Government agreed to change our 1995 prisons programme and that nothing happened for a full year and the delay is caused by that?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: The truth is nothing happened for seven years when the Deputy's party was in office.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: And nothing will as long as the Taoiseach is in office.

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: Not good ground for the Deputy.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Dempsey Mr. Dempsey
Speaker.P: Was it not the Taoiseach who said there were too many people in prison in April 1995?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cowen Mr. Cowen
Speaker.P: In regard to a promise made by the Taoiseach which hopefully will not require legislation, could he clarify his statement about the nurses' dispute that “it can and must be solved”? Had he in mind that it would be solved before or after they go on strike on 10 February?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Joe Jacob
Speaker.P: We cannot debate that now.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Cowen Mr. Cowen
Speaker.P: The Taoiseach does not seem to be aware of the fact that 26,000 nurses are going on strike. He is silent on the issue.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. McCreevy Mr. McCreevy
Speaker.P: Is it only the easy questions he answers?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callely Mr. Callely
Speaker.P: Has the Taoiseach any proposals on improvements in education for people with a disability, particularly in light of a recent court ruling?

Speaker.hpid: The Taoiseach John Bruton
Speaker.P: The Deputy would be advised to put down a parliamentary question in regard to all promised legislation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Callely Mr. Callely
Speaker.P: I have done so in the past.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. D. Ahern Mr. D. Ahern
Speaker.P: The Deputy will not get an answer.
